thread.title: 5 things you hate most about airlines
thread.title_full: 5 things you hate most about airlines - MarketWatch

author: Catey Hill
title: 5 things you hate most about airlines
text:
Flying is somehow even worse this year than last — that is if consumer complaints are any indication.
The number of airline customer complaints filed with the Department of Transportation this year (through June) is up more than 20% compared with the first six months of 2014, according to a government report released Tuesday .
From January 2015 to June 2015, the Department of Transportation received 9,542 complaints, up from 7,935 received during the first six months of 2014. Most of these complaints were about U.S. airlines (7,274 in total, up 21%, when compared with the same period last year).
So what’s bugging flyers? Lost, damaged and delayed baggage ranks No. 1. (That should come as no surprise, as recent data shows that more than 24 million bags are delayed, damaged, pilfered, lost or stolen under the airline industry’s watch each year .) That was followed closely by reservation, ticketing and boarding issues.

For the first six months of this year, American Airlines ( AAL, +2.45% ) (this includes both American and US Airways, which have merged) received the most complaints (2,148 total), followed by United ( UAL, +1.26% ) (1,271), which makes sense considering their large market share. But when you look at the number of complaints per boarding, a different picture emerges — with fee-happy Spirit and Frontier leading the way.

To be sure, the number of complaints may have risen, in part, because more people are flying. But that probably doesn’t explain all of the 20% jump in complaints, experts say. Some of this uptick may be due to airlines doing more policing of their baggage policies this year and weather issues, says Rick Seaney, chief executive officer of FareCompare.com , a travel advice site and search engine for flight bookings.
